Appendix C ÃÂ¢Ãâ¬Ãâ Practical cases and applications For the second case, generalized non-homothetic CES, with uniform elasticity of substitution across goods: 1. In various contexts, one has associated a lower elasticity of substitution for richer consumers (in line with empirical evidence) while keeping the practicality of CES preferences. Proposition 4 case ii) allows us to do just that. Handbury (2016) and Faber and Fally (2017) assume that the consumption of the outside good influences elasticities. Here, one can circumvent such assumption by defining utility implicitly in a similar fashion as in Hanoch (1975) and Comin et al (2015).
